reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not a stealth game, This is not Gunpoint, You cannot turn off these hints.

This actually all very good advice, Ronin is not about making a plan of how to get to the top floor without being seen, it's not about discovering the truth of a mystery without making noise.  It's exactly what a tale of a Ronin should be, revenge, destruction, and badassery.

Your best bet is to go with the flow in this game, use your rope to smash through the window and cut the guard by the entrance in half. No one noticed you? Hang half of the others from the ceiling, but then you get spotted by the super speed samuri! Jump next to the window, then jump away and watch him hilariously throw himself out the building to fall to his death after hitting some electrified wires. Your turn stops with you hanging in midair, you throw your sword at the guy at the far end of the room and land infront of another. You summon your sword to you and it flies into his back!  Launch yourself to the wall to avoid the stream bullets from the guard with the submachine, wait a turn, then cackle evily as you now have two whole turns to finish hims off any way you want becuase now he has to reload and then reaquire you. Jump to him and use your grappling hook to close in... but another default guard sees you and your rope swing doesn't clear his aim. A single tiny bullet hits and you fall to the ground clutching your wound.

The guards will come better equipped with all sorts of gadgets weapons and abilities, but all it takes is a single bullet to kill you. The really good news is that you get a checkpoint every time you enter or exit a room. this means plenty of retries that don't force you to comeback across the map, because there is going to be that room that takes 20 tries. You may get respawned dead center of all the guards, but that's because it was the only entrance to the room.

Your biggest advantage is that Ronin is turn based, plan where your gonna go and who you slice next with all the time in the world. Your turn can even (and often) end with you in midair with a nice selection of methods to dispose of the baddies. The skills can only be activated by action points, and the action points can only be acquired from stunning and killing enemies. At five points you trigger limit break wich resets your points but gives you a whole extra turn, which could be a godsend as that was all you needed to tackle the annoying guard about to set the alarm. Or it could be really annoying as sword throwing would have been really more helpful at the moment.

Your skills are granted points for completing these optional objectives:

-Killing all enemies; not a stealth game, you can be stealthy, but loud is suprisingly more fun and rewarding

-No alarms; there isn't a guard standing next to the magic game over button, you have 8 turns to at the least get his attention

-Kill no civillians; this is where your stealth play is pretty much most used, simply avoid lights to dodge the chatting civvies in some sort of puzzle fashion

Spending your skill points will mold how you paly the game, deciding which you will get more use out of is frustrating, especially when there is so many cool choices.

As for downsides, (to this fantastic game!):

-The transition between combat turns and roaming can be disorienting. You can use the pause button at any time, but if you use it when you thought you entered a room unoticed and press it right as combat starts you may think you're still roaming and lose that valuable first turn since it's your skip turn button during combat. Or think it's still combat and not notice the guard calling the alarm isn't paused, the pause button and time pause for jumping can save you there sometimes.

-The objective for almost every mission leading to the bosses is go to the computers and press the button to auto hack. Some other challenges would have been nice. Since making your way through the building and guards is the main challenge and often very different and fun, that one should slide.

-The optional objectives are also all the same. They feel more like requirements since that's how your skill points are earned, and you NEED those skill points. Minibosses and optional fullfilment objectives could have spiced things up.

-As mentioned the limit break extra turn" can be very unhelpful in certain situations. The mechanic will add a layer to tactics
date:
but an accidental stun can lose that sword toss you really needed and that will cause you some gray hairs more than once


All in all

hoursPlayed: not to easy. It's nice to see someone create an action game that doesn't sell off of hype or humor. Ronin tells you what it is
voteText: and does it very well. I'll even say it

reviewText:
RONIN would be a great experience--if it weren't so buggy. The gameplay is very enjoyable when it's working as desired, but when it's not, everything goes downhill.

Pros:
-decent art and music
-sufficient context for the game (why I'm killing people)
-enjoyable gameplay WHEN IT WORKS

Cons:
-First, let me tell you this is a turn-based game. THAT IS NOT A CON. The con is that this turn-based game only executes your desired commands 50% of the time.
-unaccurate player hitboxes
-player dropping down a ledge in the middle of a battle when you wanted to jump onto the ledge
-grappel is not easy to use in that it difficult to tell where you'll go when using small adjustments
-buggy (enemy got stuck in a wall once and couldn't attack him)
-another bug: if you're standing on the edge of a platform and you want to drop down to a lower platform, there is a certain angle where it shows you can jump down but then you're guy just stays at the same spot, wasting a turn and often getting me killed. You can understand my frustration.
-doing side-objectives, while not exactly difficult, are the only way to get much-needed upgrades
-final boss level has no checkpoints and in combination with the gameplay faults listed above, has created a frustrating experience which, in turn, has led me to write this review

To the dev--physics in this sort of game should be less prioritized than making sure the players commands get executed. For example, if I was about to hit a wall but then I use my grappel to the opposite wall, my grappel should not extend and then make me hit into the wall which is what I wanted to avoid, instead the grappel should guide my momentum to the opposite direction.

Works in some ways, doesn't in others: 5.9/10

reviewText:
Ronin is a very unique game in that it's a sort of turn-based action platformer.

I would personally recommend it due to have much of a unique game it is, despite any similarities to Gunpoint. There are a few things that would make it an even better game, such as being able to know exactly where you would be once you make a move, or being able to know if doing a certain action will kill you. A level editor would also give this game some fantastic replayability as, in its current state, the game is unfortunately rather short.  I completed it in about 4 hours or so.

Unfortunately the dev has mentioned that unless this sells 100k copies, a level editor is highly unlikely. This is a great shame as I feel it would add so much more and give players a chance to really experiment with the unique gameplay mechanics that Ronin offers.

For its price, though, Ronin is a fantastic little game that offers a unique experience you won't find anywhere else, not even in Gunpoint.

Pick it up!

reviewText:
A simple but fun sort-of-stealth turn-based platformer.

I found out about this thanks to a video from Tom Francis (Gunpoint - excellent game!), who sang its praises.

Some genuinely clever moments lead to some satisfying kills(/ing sprees). The moves unlocked as you progress really open up how you tackle facing a half dozen enemies at once. The game is very cool at times :)

Sadly some bugs do take from what is otherwise a fun experience. For eg, sometimes if you die, your checkpoint is 15 secs of mundane (at least when youre repeating it) travel back to the action. And occasionally the jump arc likes to lie to you and a pointless and unfair death follows.

That said, the game can often be found for more than 2/3's off, and at that price its an easy recommendation.

reviewText:
Stylish stealth murder simulator and turn based action rampage. (Stealth is theoretically optional, but not sneaking around picking off straglers from time to time makes combat sections far more difficult.)

-Story-
The story in Ronin is a straightforward revenge mission with not a lot new to say, and I LIKE that the game really OWNS that. They waste no time telling you things you can readily assume, or that you just don't need to know. If you are interested in this game, then you know the tropes already. You can just jump into the action and fill in the blanks yourself.

-Gameplay-
The first few missions are easy enough, and give you a chance to get some starting ninja skills in your arsenal. A ninja must be sneaky and thorough. Allowing someone to notice evidence of your presence without actively threatening them starts them phoning for help, so stray bullets alerting the next room are almost as bad as them hitting you. Eventually you'll start encountering large rooms where enemies guard eachother from all angles, and even from neighboring buildings. Planning and trickery are required to thin their numbers down to manageable levels before you reveal your presence and start turn-based combat. The difficulty ramps up suddenly in a few places, but fortunately the automatic checkpoints are generous.

-Controls-
The game's controls do take a little getting used to, and when you drop into turn based combat you lose some of the flexibility you enjoyed moving around in real time. That can make certain movement tricks difficult or impossible once the bullets start flying. The jump arc indicator does not take the loss of momentum from crashing into enemies into account, and jumping to corners can leave you in unexpected positions. I also experienced a few places where the grappling hook triggered clipping problems, and I ended up on the opposite side of the ceiling from where I wanted to be. Not ideal, but overall manageable.

There is a downside to the game being so light on text: some of the more subtle mechanics are not obvious. They make complete sense in retrospect, but not having them pointed out is a learning curve. For instance, I see some reviewers have complained that the enemy AI is inconsistent about when they can spot you or not, and that seems to be because those people have not noticed or understood the light/darkness mechanic. A ninja in the dark is undetectable, and an enemy in the dark is easy to pick off. Only by standing in the light do the poor guards have any hope of having the alarm raised and their murder avenged. Fits the ninja theme perfectly, but only obvious in hindsight. Perhaps an addition to the very helpful hints" could be patched in.

-Sound-
The music is a joy. It fits well with the changing level of action
date:
and doesn't get old even after hours of hearing the same loops. I do wish more of the chapter finales had music as sweet as Chapter 2.

-Time/replayability-
Ronin is a bit on the short side

reviewText: This game could use some more polish - the jump arc is finicky and more than a few times straight up didn't match up to where I landed at all. Sometimes landing on a wall or ceiling will glitch you on the other side, or might just teleport you across the map. It would be nice to have a better understanding of the character's hitbox. The quick trial and error gameplay doesn't match with the few seconds of loadtime before restarting, and checkpoint placement often seems thoughtless, putting your character at the top of an elevator ride, or back before you hacked a computer.\n\nBut this game is ultimately totally worth playing because when it does work it's rad as hell. Great concept with a solid excecution. Once you get the hang of the grappling hook, and get skills like throwing and recalling your sword, the game is a joy to play. It's a trial and error type of game where you will die and restart a lot, but when you get that perfect run it feels amazing. Knock people out of windows, grapple swing 270 degrees around a platform and land on a guy, throw your sword at a dude and swing around to catch it in midair - it's all great.

reviewText:
HINT: This is not gunpoint.

No hint from the game dev, it definitely is not.

While it's kinda fun, RONIN lacks a story of any kind really, mangles together a very strange mix of free roaming throughout the stage and turn-based combat the moment your spotted, and tends to throw a ton of enemies at you who can all one shot you, but you have to get within stabbing distance or use one of your skills (which require skill points that you earn) in order to kill them.  Oh, and there are special enemy types, including some regular grunts that will do nothing but call in the lockdown command, a giant samurai who if you land anywhere near him or jump over his personal space in mid-combat, he will, without even using a turn, kill you instantly, and a swat looking grunt that uses a machine gun.

I cannot count the number of times where I have had to desparately bounce around a room because every time I land, my enemies line up another shot on me, and if I dont move out of the line of fire, i'm dead.  However, since I can't get behind cover very often (it's pretty rare) and kill someone without taking fire, I have to just keep bouncing around and either come up with some elaborate plan ahead of time, or hope I get lucky and just get a small openning with which to pick off ONE of probably 6+ enemies.  Also, since combat is turn based, I can't just turn that off temporarily, run somewhere very quickly while they continue to line up a shot (as they would do on their next turn anyway), and then turn the turn based back on.  This has multiple times lead to me being trapped by fire on multiple sides and having to sit there, and forfeit turns, just so I don't die.  Oh, and the skills I mentioned?  Very lacking in variety.  You actually have to spend skill points on empty spots to get to the final skill point of each tree" (calling it a twig would be more appropriate.  most all of the twigs only have 2 to 3 skills at most

reviewText:
I found the game far more frustrating than engaging.  The turn-based combat is clunky, with the forced jumping infuriating.    Many times I just needed to walk one or two feet, but wasn't allowed to.  This is made worse with the inaccurate jump arc.  I died far too many times from accidentily knocking-out an enemy and being pushed into an unexpected position.

Open engagements with a dozen enemies are an exercise in patience, jumping in circles and waiting for reloads just to be able to pick off one enemy.  Even then, it's sometimes possible to be shot through a solid floor or wall.

I couldn't bring myself to play through even half of the game with these issues.  For me, Ronin is not worth buying at any price.

reviewText:
Unfortunately this is a very poorly designed game, the controls are extremely finicky and only work sometimes, causing you to die in stupid ways that aren't even your fault.  No stealth, which is fine, though I don't know why it's tagged as stealth, but it seems more like it's trying to be hotline miami than gunpoint since gunpoint was all about doing it your way, whereas this almost always has one correct way of clearing a room, and it's just not that good.  It's got some cool ideas, and when you pull off a level perfectly it can be very satisfying, but those moments are few and far between. Much of it is trying to deal with the weird controls, lack of knowledge on what's actually going on in the level and poor level design.

The game isn't hard because it's strategic, it's hard because pulling that strategy off without your character moving an inch forward, instead of jumping to the ceiling like you told him to, or stopping in the middle of enemy fire for some reason, or the character just straight up not doing what you told him to - is a constant issue.

In order to make a strategy, you need to react to the information provided, the problem is that information is wrong most of the time. The game might tell you that if you jump in X area you're in the clear, but then you do that and get shot anyways because your character jumped a few feet back from it and got shot for no good reason. It's infuriating.

And in a game like this, where responsiveness is absolutely essential since you die in one hit, these problems are fatal for the game, and are reason enough for me to not recommend it.

reviewText: So, the game itself, I wouldn't call horrible, but its buggy, has bad controls, and the load time can get annoying as hell. The game is difficult, but this is mostly caused by the bugs and bad controls. The game can be fun at times, but it needs a lot of work. The game is also very very repetetive, mission wise. It's pretty much break into the building, kill everyone, get on the motorcycle. While a lot of games do this, I really expected more from Ronin.\n\nP.S. The grapple hook is horrible.

reviewText: This game got so frustrating with it's inconsistent rules that I had to uninstall. You can bust a window out in one level and no one will hear anything, Then you bust out a window and some guy two levels below you can hear you and now the game's difficulty is way too high and eventually just starts being unfair. Won't be playing this game again until it's out of early access and the first update has been made.\n\nSet your rules and don't abuse them just to put pressure on the player.

reviewText: Bought this on a whim, since I remembered it from a Kotaku feature or something and it was on sale. Similar to Gunpoint, but with much deeper and more intuitive turn-based combat mechanics. There's definitely huge satisfaction in a perfectly-executed series of kills; in this sense aspects of the game are Hotline Miami-esque (although the two play very differently). The minimalist, slightly futuristic visual design also works pretty well. I would recommend this game at full price; if you see it on sale, absolutely pick this one up!

reviewText:
It's a very cool update on Gunpoint's mechanics.

*IT IS NOT AN ACTION OR STEALTH GAME* (there is a little of each)

It's a tactical game. You have free movement till combat initiates, at which point everything is turn based. So you've got plenty of time to decide where to jump, what to kill, who to knock through which window...  It's a lot of fun.

Unfortunately, it's eventually let down by the imprecise controls, which are not nearly tight or capable enough to handle things from the fourth level boss on.  It's at that point that you'll die, and die a lot, and worse, only part of the time will it feel like your fault.  But even with that still very worth playing.

reviewText: This game has a unique design to be sure. You might associate turn-based" with strategy or tactics

"turn-based action" perfectly fits this game since there isn't much thinking involved. But who cares? How often do you get to play a female ninja who doges bullets left and right while cutting enemies into fine slices?

Riddles in it are easy to solve (as expected of an action game) and the only brain teaser might be "how do I get past that civilian in bright as day light without killing him or him noticing me?" to do all optional objectives. Alternatively you can just slaughter everyone.

reviewText: This game is amazing. A simple yet effective and completely unique main mechanic drives the gameplay. It's not only fun to play, but you feel like a true ninja when you win. It's short, but well worth the price!

date: you go ahead and play. The story will be here if you're interested. The graphics are simple but fun

reviewText:
An extremely awkward, frustrating, and poorly balanced mess with cool art.

I really like the concept here and badly want to like this game, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired....simple design decisions, such as being unable to pull yourself up a ledge or even MOVE (other than jump) in turn-based mode are only the beginning of the problems....

Ultimately, this is a shallow action combat game that has you pausing" (turn-based) the combat so you can time "perfect" jumps all over the place (remember
date:
you can't move during combat other than jump).



PROS:
-Action sequences are fun (non-turn based gameplay)
-Art style

NEUTRALS:
-Mini RPG / ability unlock system was ok but felt slightly out of place (not sure how I earned the ability points
recommended:
seems like you get 1 per level)

CONS:
-The turn-based components are there
hoursPlayed: in essence. However
voteText: the core of the game is built around an action game (dodging the shots
helpfulPercent: etc) and with little to no stealth mechanics or other "strategy" component
votesHelpful: it leaves for a very confusing and frustrating turn-based experience.\n\n-Can't MOVE in turn-based mode. WTF? You can ONLY JUMP
votesTotal: so if you are hanging off a ledge
votesFunny: you cannot pull yourself up.  NUMEROUS times there will be combat areas with excessive edges. During these sequences expect to die+restart countless times because your character automatically grabs ledges
column16: you are basically a sitting duck unless you happen to have an arc you can jump away from since you cannot do anything else. Frustrating and extremely stupid design.\n\n-Many actions simply disappear when you are (forced) in turn-based mode. For example
column17: those stairs you just climbed down? Sorry can't climb them in turn-based mode.\n\n-Lockdown mechanic: If an enemy loses sight of you
column18: they will automatically initiate a lockdown in 10 "turns." Since not triggering the alarm is an objective in every mission
column19: and since you CANNOT MOVE during turn-based combat
column20: this means you have to "jump" (1 jump = 1 turn) over to that enemy so that he does see you and stops his 10-turn countdown.....in almost every instance of doing this
column21:
some OTHER enemy will now lose sight of you and immediately begin na 10-turn lockdown counter.....extremely annoying.

-Atrocious level design and pacing. Most of the level is reasonably easy and then out of nowhere a room that is near impossible. Several places in the levels have ledges which grossly interfere with gameplay due to the inability to move properly during combat.

-TERRIBLE documentation. Absolutely abysmal. Virtually nothing is documented.

-No UI information for a "turn based" game (for example
column22: the robot looking minigunners appearing in mission 3 shoot their gun for 2 turns
column23: but the only way to know this is by trial and error).\n\nTIP:  The game bugs out at resolutions above 1920x1080 but it is hard to tell that it is bugging out. If your combat icons do not appear above the enemies
column24: and you are having a hard time with the controls
column25: try running in windowed mode or reducing resolution."

reviewText:
RONIN, a game that looks like a stealth game but is actually just a trigger-happy trap.

Can I kill this enemy sillently while being in the dark ?
No, because the other guy will look that way exactly at that moment.

The turned-based idea is great, the animation is good, the artistic design is deluxe but that is not enough to keep me from hating the triggers in the game.

reviewText: The artstyle looks like the games developed by Klei which is a really nice thing. The music is used sparsely but fits the dystopian thriller-feeling but the story is non-existant. Anything else would be a lie. Another lie (contributed by Steam reviewers) that this game is a stealth game which it is definetly not. You have almost no option to sneak, so Ronin is an action-platformer with turn based combat. The gameplay works but in my opinion the game design has some flaws. For example the skills you unlock. You can only use them, when you use a form of combo which is stupid in my opinion. Also the AI is too picky for me. But all of this would be ok if this had not been so repetetive. You arrive at a level. You need to hack computers, engage in some combat, hack another computer, engage in combat again. Then you leave and have to get to your motorbike WHICH IS IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION OF ARRIVAL. The game is a 7/10. Can't really recommend it, there are better games to play in my opinion. The game is not bad though, by any means.

reviewText:
There is a lot to love about Ronin. It has a really excellent astethic. Good music. Intersting mechanics.

But it does two things that really really bother me.

#1. You have to finish an entire level in one sitting. The checkpoints only save in a game session. Sometimes I get frustrated and want to play something else. Give it a break. Can't do that.

#2. The game has no real tutorial or explenation of it's mechanics. I don't mind learning. But I'm probably doing some things sub-optimally because I've not been instructed properly.

reviewText:
I would like to first mention that if you just want an overview it's gonna be at the bottom but if you want to see in depth why I don't recommend this game at all you can keep reading. We're gonna go from Story to Gameplay to Audio to Overview to Thoughts and Opinions. (Note: Anything in paranthesis can be ignored but adds my own thoughts. This review assumes you saw the gameplay trailer above and slight spoilers although the game is so boring and generic that I don't think they are actually spoilers)

Story: There is none. You're some generic dude who has a vendetta against 5 (generic) people for an unknown reason. I assume your dudes name is Ronin. So Ronin goes off to kill (in order) an old dude, arrogant chick, swordsman dude, scientist, and just some dude (gonna give the game more credit than it deserves and say hes' a mob boss even tho the game makes no mention to this). That's it. Right before each mission where you kill them, Ronin makes some uninteresting remark about the target. They have names but I couldn't tell you them off the top of my head for the life of me. All I know is that the old man is called Old Man"

Gameplay: It's garbage. I hate this game. This game has 1 weapon
recommended: a grappling hook. And a skill tree. To unlock points for the skill tree you have to meet requirements on every level. They are as follows: 1. Killing all gaurds
hoursPlayed: 2. Not setting off an alarm
voteText: (this pretty much goes hand in hand with killing all the gaurds btw) and 3. Not killing civs.\nSo every level is the same ♥♥♥♥. Go in buildings
helpfulPercent: kill all gaurds
votesHelpful: hack computers to find the targets
votesTotal: leave. There are like 4 enemy types in this game. Regular gaurd
votesFunny: gaurd that you have to stun before he calls HQ to set off the alarm
column16: and swordsman. That's it. So I'm gonna assume the targets are (and I use this word loosely) bosses. They are terrible. Old man doesn't resist. Girl chick acts like a normal gaurd
column17: swordsman is like a regular swordsman (except he's wearing fancy red armor)
column18: scientist dude kills himself on accident (in the trailer is shows you chasing him but somehow he jumps out a window and misses the next window in my 2 playthroughs) and some dude just acts like a normal gaurd.\nHere's the main thing wrong with this game: It highly recommends controller
column19: I highly recommend that you DON'T use the controller. I beat the main game with controller cuz I had one but it was so agonizing and unresponsive. So this game requires you to be VERY precise with where Ronin is and moves because one ♥♥♥♥ up and you're dead. But I gaurantee that over 50% of your deaths are gonna come from Ronin doing something you didn't want him to do. In the trailer it doesn't show it but you can hop down through ledges. So there's a little icon telling you when Ronin is about to jump and frequently you put the icon to jump and this guy doesn't go through. He hops over 2 inches on the ledge you told him to go through. I have died so many times it's so frustrating. It made me want to punch a hole in my monitor so many times. This game's controls were not polished and leads to anger. The skills are whatever. I feel like they should all be there from the beginning because this game is broken but whatever (Need a reason to not kill the civs I guess). Nothing in this game is satisfying

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overall this game has potential, they just need to fix the combat and the level design: here are the problems they have:
The game is far too based on tiny movements, you need to have exact positioning
It is a complete pain to complete some of the levels, and most of the time you're just jumping around until you finally get some oppertunity to kill someone
It's way too difficult half the time
It's just annoying because people are only knocked down for two turns and you have to deal with 7 of them.
Stealth barely exists, in my opinion they should have more stealth skills and make every level completable in stealth.
The machine gun guards need a cone of fire, not a line.

That being said there are a few things that I think would fix the game, for example
Guards having friendly fire, since it would be interesting to be able to use the decoy to get guards to shoot eachother
Actually making stealth an option
Giving exact representations of where you'll land and in what position at the end of a turn
Making it so that the optional objectives aren't as much of a pain isn't required really but just make more of them and change them from level to level.
Maybe make it so that the skill things drain every other turn instead of every turn.
Making it so that there's a skill where in one turn you can jump to and kill someone, maybe it would cost around 3 and has a short range but it would be useful.

All in all I wouldn't recomend it at the moment but if they tone down the difficulty and overall pain of completing half the levels I'd say it would be worth it.
The problem is that I'd prefer it to be every few turns you can kill someone but at the moment it's basically try to dodge everything and if you're next to someone kill them.
(by the way I got to the third boss then couldn't complete it and gave up, because my entire screen was red lines pretty much)

reviewText:
It's a really, really cool game. If you're good enough, you actually feel like some sort of ninja, popping inside a building and leaping around massacring everyone.

HOWEVER, the experience is hindered by the clunky control and the unreliable mechanic. Even after more than an hour of playing I still having difficulty controlling my jump. And unreliablity: sometimes when the samurai enemy lands nearby, I got slain right away, while another time I randomly not get slain. This kind of chaotic mechanic is good for a real-time gameplay, but is a big no-no for a turn-based gameplay since you want to plan your moves ahead.

Also, I finished the first 5 levels in an hour, and there are only 15 levels? =/

reviewText: Ronin is a turn-based action PUZZLE. The idea is good but badly executed. All my wins are only based on lots of try-and-error.\nIn here, your in-game skill needs to charge in a rather slow phase. Most of the time you want to use those skills but turns out you are still charging. The combating system is very confusing either. The rules of jumping and moving between platform is constantly changing.\nIf you must buy an action/stealth game, try gunpoint or mark of the ninja.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText: RONIN is so close to being good. I had fun slicing guards and swinging from the ceilings, it was enjoyable, until i reached the final level. This game could have been amazing if they nailed a few control problems and made it a bit longer, but the sore thumb of this game is the final level. first of all the level design of the final level makes stealth (which is a large portion of the game, but not neccessary to beat the game) almost impossible, I don't mind changing the gameplay near the end, but there is a difference between slowly changing the gameplay near the end, and just making the final level completely different from the rest. This game could have been great if the final level was fixed, or even just cut, the level before it was miles higher in quality. So in summary, the game was great except for a few control design decisions, and the last level. What a shame. :/\n\nP.S. If i got anything wrong please tell me, I really want to like this game, and if I'm just to dumb to see something that everyone else does please tell me. Thanks! ;)

reviewText: I like it a lot. As a stealth games veteran, it's not so hard, even on plus mode and the game itself is little bit rough on the edges, all together comes up pretty nice. Mechanics are fair and straight, level designs are just right when it comes to amount of stealth and open turn-based fight You have (it is possible to do a lot of ceiling-hanging, try harder!), graphics and sounds doesn't make me irritated. It has this ONE MORE TURN (or in this case actually more TRY)" syndrome which is enough to recommend. 1-2 evenings of fun and I was enjoyed and satisfied every time when finished a level. Looking forward for next game of Tomasz Waclawek. Good job man!"

reviewText: Fun, and fairly short to really beat thoroughly(4 hrs for all optional objective playthrough, 9 for that + new game plus playthrough). I have to give it negative marks for the last level, which completely changes how the game works. Goes from checkpoints allowing you to slowly but surely progress through the level, into having to do the entire level in one go. I only encountered one, but there are also some physics bugs where I jumped into a fake 'room' that couldn't be escaped. I'll change my review to positive if the developer ever fixes the last level.

reviewText:
I'd love to recommend this fully, but I can't. Review is positive, because i bought it -75% chaper and it was fun through the game for the majority of time. If the price is still low give it a shot. Overall the game feels simply incomplete. I think it is great groundwork for something more.

PROS:
- Idea
- Nice, miningfull upgrades
- Combat is so satisfying once executed well (especially with throwing sword, calling it into someones back etc)

CONS
- My god, the controls... Most of it works fine, but it is so imprecise. Generally I feel like I have more control over character out of the combat than in turn based fight. (I cant move while in combat? wtf...)
- Level design is not great. It's not bad either; it's just a bit boring. Most of the time I went through without problem doing all objectives.

reviewText: This game takes an interesting concept and executes it poorly.  The turn based system works best when it is predictible.  This is not the case.  The game gives indicators where your character will move, but fails to give accurate data.  This leads to frustration that doesn't feel like the players fault.  Graphically, the game is pleasing (muscially as well).  I would not recommend this game purely due to the lack of enjoyment it brings.

reviewText: Initaly I loved this game but the more I play the more the inconsistencies of it's execusion fustrate me. The on screen player tips remind us 'the reticlue lies' but this doesnt lessen the fustration as no pattern to these 'fibs' is, for me at least, apparent. The grapple also behaves inconsistenly sometimes firing after the dots turn black (to signify a valid move) sometimes not. Worst of all there is a set turn time before guards call back up (often 8 turns) but on occasion, mid fight, the turn based  counter is replaced with a real time count down that can mean a fustrating end to a fight. This has happened to me on a number occasions and spoiled some, up to that point, to plan battles. I would love to recomend this game but it feels to me that tweaking is required. As Giant Bomb suggested: a shadow displaying where ronin will actually move to on the next turn could help as at present the game feels to rely too heavily on trial and error. If you have not played Mark of The Ninja I would recomend you grab that instead. At least for now.

reviewText:
This review was written for FREEDOM Community Gaming Collective[freedomcgc.com].
Because of its visual style, it’s extremely easy to get the wrong idea about Ronin. Take a look at one screenshot and you’ll think it’s similar to Gunpoint. Take a look at another and it will remind you of Mark of the Ninja. Don’t judge a book by its cover, goes the old saying, and in Ronin’s case, it’s certainly true. Ronin doesn’t actually play anything like either of those games. Ronin is an odd beast filled with contradictions. It’s an action game, but its combat system is turn-based. It’s a 2D side-scrolling platformer and yet it doesn’t really compare to any platformer you’ve ever played. It has stealth elements, but it bluntly states that it is not a stealth game and advises the player to simply kill everyone.

Ronin has a razor-sharp focus on the gameplay which is reflected in the fact that the story is extremely simple. Its most obvious inspiration is Kill Bill as Ronin tells the tale of a katana-wielding heroine on a bloody revenge path. The entire story is delivered through approximately 20 short lines of text and there’s no mucking about. They killed your father. Now you kill them. The end.

So how does it play? At first glance, it really does come off as your regular side-scrolling platformer. Until you encounter your first enemy, that is. Once an enemy spots you, the turn-based system kicks in. Seeing as how Ronin’s protagonist only wields a katana, the goal is to get close to the enemy and cut him down. During your turn, you can plan your next jump using a dynamic jump arc, attack an enemy or use certain abilities or gadgets that may be at your disposal depending on the situation. During this planning phase, you will be able to see the next move your enemies will make as well. If they’re aiming at the location you are currently occupying, you will have to move as the game employs a one shot, one kill rule. You can jump on enemies to knock them out for a couple of turns and you can also jump into them which will send them flying either into another enemy bringing him down as well or out of the window for a one way trip to digital hell. You have a grappling hook at your disposal as well which will come in handy when trying to escape a particularly unfavorable situation. The tool is also necessary for traversing almost each level as you will use it to hurl yourself through windows, for example.

You can unlock abilities and gadgets by completing optional objectives in each mission which pretty much makes these objectives obligatory or else you’ll simply be at a disadvantage in the next level. These objectives are always the same – don’t trigger the alarm, don’t kill civilians and kill all enemies. The good thing is that completing these objectives doesn’t feel like a chore at all, doing a perfect run is extremely satisfying. The unlockable abilities and gadgets facilitate more diverse gameplay and range from being able to leave a decoy which will distract enemies for a couple of turns to teleporting near an enemy and stunning him.

Your next move will also depend on your enemies and your surroundings. Different enemies will follow different patterns. Ordinary enemies will aim and then shoot until they empty their gun clip at which point they will have to reload leaving you with a welcomed window of opportunity. Enemies equipped with assault rifles will shoot at the same location for two turns whereas samurais will charge straight at you even across great distances. As far as the surroundings are concerned, sometimes you’ll be able to strike unseen from the shadows whereas other times your progress will be hampered by mines and laser beams. Naturally, you can use these obstacles in your favor by jump-kicking enemies into them. While Ronin is a relatively straightforward game, all of these elements contribute to some engaging emergent gameplay as you try out different tactics each time. And even though the level design isn’t really open-ended, it is extremely important to survey the entire level first as that will provide some insight regarding the most optimal course of action.

Ronin is also a very stylish game. The visual style is relatively simple yet pleasing and clear. It actually reminded me of old Cartoon Network shows such as Samurai Jack. Certain characters reminded me of Professor Utonium from the Powerpuff Girls with their rectangular heads. Animations are also very stylish and smooth, although it would be nice if our heroine had some more execution animations. Overall, it’s a great art style. I also need to mention the superb soundtrack that sets the mood perfectly. Even though the track list is relatively sparse, it still greatly contributes to the overall badassery of the game. The main complaint I have with the game are the controls which simply do not offer the kind of pinpoint precision you require from a game like this. Make no mistake, they’re far from bad, but they could’ve still used some fine-tuning as it’s not really uncommon to fumble up a move as the jump arc is a bit fiddly to maneuver. Also, there is one extremely hard and annoying level which absolutely requires you to go about it in a very specific way. It simply hurts the emergent gameplay and even when you figure it out, it’s still really hard to complete. It just sticks out from the rest of the game.

Even though it can be frustrating at times due to its not-quite-perfect controls a bit of trial-and-error, Ronin is still a thoroughly great game thanks to its stylish presentation, innovative mechanics, emergent gameplay and well-designed levels.

8 OUT OF 10 (GREAT)

reviewText: I got this game on the humble bundle for about a dollar, and I'd say it was worth it cause god DAMN this game. I dont know how to feel about it.\n\nAs it states, it is a turn based ninja combat game, where you have to dodge red lines that indicate enemy attacks while at the same time trying to kill off the enemies. Thats, pretty much it. No variety and stealth is pretty much needed because, well, you're a ninja. Unfortunately you have to deal with enemies much more then you do actual ninja'ing stuff. This game is fun, I wont lie. But its the fact that it outright FORCES combat onto you is something that annoy's me greatly. I've been stealthing as much as I can for the sole purpose to avoid fighting, because after a while it is VERY repetitive. Absolutely no thought went into the gameplay as a whole, which even though it goes for something new, its ironically one of its few weakest points in the game. There's an upgrade screen, but even that feels lackluster in its attempt because its just Spend a point on nothing to get closer to that one particular skill". reviewText:
Mi ha sorpreso. A livello di gameplay e stile è simile a Gunpoint, questo salta subito all'occhio. E' un indie realizzato da un sola persona, che pur con i suoi evidenti difetti, avrebbe meritato una metacritic maggiore di quella che ha (70). I difetti sono comunque non troppo pesanti: qualche imprecisione nei controlli, qualche checkpoint non posizionato benissimo, poca varietà dei livelli e una difficoltà non sempre ben calibrata.

Ronin è si difficile, ma tremendamente appagante, quasi al livello di Hotline Miami. Nonostante le imprecazioni l'ho trovato molto stimolante. Peccato un po' per l'ultimissimo livello, senza checkpoint stavo seriamente considerando di disinstallarlo con un ragequit, fortunatamente sono riuscito a scamparla in una delle innumerevoli run.

C'è una modalità new game plus, ma sinceramente mi sento sazio dopo 9 ore passate col gioco (dato che tra l'altro dovrebbe durarne di meno, sulle 6). Lo consiglio senza riserve, come ho detto ha i suoi difetti ma una giocata la merita assolutamente.

reviewText: The core mechanic is solid but the game suffers from uneven difficulty in level design and underutilized stealth. You cannot kill the lights even when you are exactly near them. Skill unlocks are available only when you finish the level perfectly (no alarms, no civs killed and I forgot the third rule). If you can't get the perfect score, too bad. Without those the game is pretty hard at times. Another thing that's bugging me is that AI bullets go through different AIs. It would be much cooler if you could position yourself to lead AI to shoot each other. Changing these obvious things would make the game much better, IMHO. Gotta hope the author makes a sequel.\n\nStill, it's cheap and good enough to play through.

reviewText: At its best, RONIN is like playing a tightly choreographed fight scene. The controls are fairly unforgiving (you'll accidentally jump into power lines or directly into the path of a bullet more than once), and it takes a while to get used to them, but when the game clicks it is one of the most satisfying melee systems I've ever used. The flow of the game is very much reliant on trying, dying and repeating, but intentionally so. While it may sometimes get frustrating tackling the same room of enemies for the fifth time in a row, trying to kill them all without setting off an alarm, when you finally do it is immensely satisfying. The game isn't perfect, but it's a fantastic experience.

reviewText:
Ronin is to games what B-movies are to film - you can tell it exists because other designs inspired its look and feel, but it's an enjoyable enough diversion that the borrowing doesn't offend. Spend any time at all with the game and you'll see its heritage - titles like Gunpoint, Mark of the Ninja and Splinter Cell: Conviction. However, its stealth game heritage has been flavored with doses of Transistor and Hotline Miami, creating something which only looks like  a stealth game.  Stealth kills are available (and necessary at times for three starring levels), but ghosting through a building undetected by all and sundry will not happen - there are going to be several set pieces on each level when you will have to draw your katana and go to work. In combat, if you get hit once, you die, but checkpoints are plentiful and other than the last level, you never need to replay more than your current room.

Killing in Ronin is a turn-based system of taking jumps, knocking enemies down and finding windows in which to finish them off. As you level up, you'll get some extra advantages (decoys, thrown weapons, teleport stuns, etc.), but they never sidestep the core of the experience. At the end of the game, it will still be you, your sword and a bunch of enemy laser sights to avoid. And when everything plays out well, you'll come out feeling just as satisfied as you would after a particularly obnoxious level of Hotline Miami.

There are three kinds of enemies: pistol-packing security guards, armored guards with assault rifles and cybernetic samurai with blades (there are also a few bosses sprinkled in). Each is different - the pistoleros fire single shots while the riflemen put down suppressive fire that is dangerous to leap through (but are consequently slower to shift aim points). Cybernetic samurai take two hits to kill (a stun and then a quick follow up hit).  There are also a few environmental hazards (long falls, laser grids and sensor activated mines) to be navigated - fortunately, all of these can be used against enemies. The enemy A.I. is adequate and has patterns which you will learn to exploit over the game.

To level up, you need to satisfy three criteria on each level - spare the civilians, kill all the guards and prevent the alarm. Sparing civilians is generally a matter of planning (how to dispatch guards without being seen, which should be old hat to any stealth pro). Killing all the guards is just a best practice. The last criteria is the most annoying - during combat, guards will sometimes try to trigger the lockdown, putting you on a clock to stun them (civilians will also trigger the alarm but are much easier to avoid). In large fights (and especially those where there are mutually supporting enemies in different buildings), this can cause a significant amount of tooth gnashing and cursing.

I thought the game controlled reasonably well, except for the grappling hook, which was a bit swingy. The code for walls and windows is a bit off and you will sometimes clip through them, which is sloppy. The soundtrack is first rate, the art design is consistent and the graphics are crisp, so good marks for presentation. The writing, however, is both sparse and weak (even the digital comic offers no real insight into why there is such an all-consuming need for vengeance), but if you go at Ronin with the mindset that it is a diversion and not a meal, you'll be fine.

Length would seem to be about 5-6 hours, I'll let you make your own judgment on what is an acceptable price for that time. There is a new game plus available after finishing the core game for those who want to go at it all again.

reviewText: The amount of negative reviews surprised me at first, but it's easy to see where they come from. The developer proudly proclaims that Ronin is a ripoff of Gunpoint, which makes people think two incorrect things about this game: a. it's a ripoff of Gunpoint, and b. it's based around stealth. The big thing that proves these assumptions wrong is that in Gunpoint you get bonuses for killing nobody where in Ronin you get bonuses for killing everybody. Ronin is short but addictive, and it's more unique than it gives itself credit for as a turn-based murder-platformer. Definitely worth grabbing on sale due to its size.

reviewText:
RONIN is a game tha has a great concept but falls flat due to lack of polish and detail, in my opinion. The concept of sneaking around and going into complexes where you use great leaping, critical thinking and flexibility skills to slip or slash your way through complexes to enact revenge is an awesome idea. The game has great and a unique art style and everything has a feeling of adventure with an overtone of revenge to it. The controls are simple but very unique and can lead to moments where you really feel like an urban rogue assassin who intends on getting the job done as efficiently as possible.

HOWEVER, the game is insanely short for the price of 13 dollars (or 20 if you wanted that soundtrack and comic so badly.). It's only a good 4 hours long if you intend to just finish it and, to me, the mechnanics can get iffy quite easily. For example, on a controller, I have great reaction abiity due to being able to just press a face button to chop someone in haf the moment I crash through a window and get an edge in the fight, but using the right thumbstick to jump can easily lead to major mistakes without even meaning it due to the control being very specific on how you release the jump. On the other hand with a mouse and keyboard I can aim my jumps very well, but I have to click on buttons to do actions. Which can easily lead to me being chopped in half if I need to do an action right then. The camera always locking into a specific position every time a fight starts out does not help.

There's no real story either (in the main game anyway) You're just some Ronin who feels wronged by a group of individuals and are determined to kill each one of them. The game never explains why you want to kill them, who you are, and who these people are in general: No names, no backgrounds, nothing.

TLDR: Great concept of a game with good visuals, but there needs to be a story of some kind of this kind of deal and the mechanics need polish and possibly new functions to help make it easier to play the game. Wait for this game to go on a real sale before buying, and even then don't expect hours of gameplay.

reviewText:
In comparison to Transistor, this is a really poorly executed turn-based game. I keep running into wall glitches where I can't kill the boss or I can't get back into the stage. It has a really sweet concept, but at the end it's near impossible to complete. It's highly frustrating.

On another note, there's something else that really sucks about RONIN. In order to become more powerful, you have to clear stages perfectly. Just about halfway through the game you'll run into instances where it's impossible to either not kill the civilians or set off the alarm.

All in all your money is better spent on Transistor. It's labeled as a stealth game, but there's very little you can do while in stealth. Besides that, there's very little you can continue to do in stealth as the game progresses. It becomes a game of turn-based oh crap who's aiming at me now?" kind of thing. You dodge bullets endlessly

reviewText: The turn based combat and jumping in Ronin are fun, but is hamstrung by several bugs and bad design choices. On many occasions, when using the grapling hook to pull up to a celing, or when falling to a floor, your character will end up on the wrong side of the floor, and often be stuck in limbo, requiring you to load a checkpoint. Enemies all have a certain number of shots they can take before needing to reload, but there's no indication for how many. Which often has multiple foes trading off who gets to kill you, leaving you no option to take out anyone else.\nI did enjoy the game though, it was just a slog to get through it. The systems are fun to mess around with, and when you get the hang of it it's a crazy thing to see play out. Just be ready for frustration when the game decides to randomly break on you, and you're once again loading the room you almost completed before randomly ending up in the foundation.

reviewText: RONIN could've been great, it should've been great and were it not for the main mechanic being broken, it would've been great.\nI'm talking about the jumping in RONIN. When you jump (something you'll spend the majority of your time in combat doing) an arc shows you where you land. Well, where you SHOULD land. The thing is that often times you'll end up hanging centimeters away from your destination in midair or completely pass through a platform you wanted to land on and vice versa. Because of this major issue, I can't recommend RONIN.

reviewText:
EDIT: I retried the level that made me ragequit after it crashed just before the end of the level. I got to the same point and. . .it crashed again, but in a completely different way. That makes a total of 3 crashes on this one level, two of them at the very end, all progress lost.

This is very close to being a game I could get obsessed with. The core gameplay is extremely fun--a really nice mix of action and strategy. It's just not ready to be released, yet. It's just too buggy and the controls are way too sloppy and inconsistent. A few examples. . .

--Bugs--
*The game crashes roughly once every three levels, usually while reloading from checkpoints. Expect to have your progress reset constantly, often during the final fight of a level.
*The thing that prompted me to write this review was a moment where the game put me in a lose state, teleported me through a wall, and immediately checkpointed me. I just had to quit the game, losing all progress. This isn't the first time I've been checkpointed just after being put in a lose state by this game, but it was definitely the most frustrating, right at the end of a long level.
*I've played under three hours and had the game crash on me around four times, and checkpoint me in unwinnable states twice. That's not counting the fact that the game simply does not run on one of my computers.

--Bad Controls--
*The entire game is about avoiding the gunfire from half a dozen guards as you jump around killing them, but the line that tells you where you're going to jump to lies. Things like colliding with an enemy will leave you in a completely unexpected location, almost always getting you killed. Expect a long and frustrating learning period as you learn
*Hitboxes in general are a mystery, which is a bad thing in a game all about precise movement. It's extremely hard to predict where you'll be standing after you kill an enemy, or how tall you'll be standing after a jump, and getting this even a little wrong is instant death. There are fun challenges and frustrating challenges, and trying to guess which if you're going to take a step into a bullet's trajectory or not in order to stab a guard is a frustrating challenge.
*The only way to move in a fight is jumping. This is almost okay, but there are a bunch of moments where jumping simply doesn't work. It's easy to end up in a situation where you need to get up on a ledge, and out of combat you'd be able to just climb up the side effortlessly, but because you're in a fight you have to spend multiple turns hopping around and spamming grappling hooks in the hopes that your momentum will deposit you awkwardly on the lip of the platform you're trying to get on instead of drifting you into a bullet or back where you started from.
*Movement just feels very rough and non-generous in general. Expect a lot of the game to be taken up by guards getting knocked out of your kill range because you jumped at them wrong or just little fiddly things going wrong.
*Stealth is baffling. I still don't understand when guards/civilians can/can't see me, which isn't a good thing since a civilian seeing you is an instant lose condition.

This is so close to being one of my favorite games of the last few months, but all of the good stuff about it just makes all the bad stuff that much more frustrating. If even half of the stuff I posted about here gets addressed I'll change my review to an enthusiastic thumbs up, but if that doesn't happen I can't recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText: while this game is awesome on so many different levels, the bugs and general technical issues that come with it make it almost impossible to play. random phazing through walls, enimies that some how heard something from before you died and restarted, the ninja not attacking from the expected angles, etc etc. realy ♥♥♥♥in awesome so long as the game cooperates. i was on a mission where i was doing excellent. all enimies killed, no alarms, and the target was dead. then trying to make it back to the motorcycle (to end the level) i decided to try some spiderman stuff and ended up phazing through the ground, unable to finish the level i just spent 30+ minutes to beat correctly. the fact that this game has been out so long and still no bug fixes makes me think the developers straight up dont give a ♥♥♥♥ anymore. needless to say, if these guys cant even patch a few bugs, im not spending any more money on them for broken games that potentially ruin my entire experience. again, i cant stress enough how much i love the gameplay and everything about this game so long as it works as intended. if you have to restart from a checkpoint multiple times is when you start seeing all the bugs.

reviewText:
Ronin has a very interesting and uniqe set of game mechanics, but the overall game design is not so good. There are many examples of the game being unfair, rather than callenging. What i mean, is when playing this game, you are going to get punished for making a mistake, that certainly is not yours, because the game is misleading, or because the mechanics are inconsitent.
You are going to waste a turn (and probably die afterwards), because the character didnt jump the way you aimed the jump. You are going to get spoted by an enemy who is standing on the opposite side of a wall. You think you are going to be able to jump down through a platform, since you could do just that with all the other platforms that looked just like it, just to find out that it didnt work, and that you are still standing on top of the it (and you wasted a turn, which probably caused your death).
The fact that this game is a turn based strategy game just makes this worse, because if you cant count on consistent mechanics in a strategy game, if the rules of the game just change in the middle of it, there is not really much strategy to it.
That being said, i really think that the core mechanics in this RONIN could make a pretty engaging game, it just does not feel like the game has been polished enough.
I could also make a long list of ideas for gameplay improvement, since i feel like the game needs a lot of changes made to the controls and gameplay. but i realize that this is not my game, and that this is not about my ideas, but the controls definately feel clumsy and just not right for a strategy game.
All in all, this game has potential, but it has a lot of holes, that a finished game should never have.

reviewText:
The game has fantastic spirit, lush retro visuals, and I really wanted to like it - gunpoint but with ninjas! But ultimately this game is janky as ♥♥♥♥. The most notable complaint is that the jump indicator lies to you, and as this is your most frequent battle action, your immersion and connection with your character is utterly broken because it DOESN'T ♥♥♥♥ING DO WHAT YOU TELL IT. A few minor changes and it could be fantastic:

- allow walking around to be one of the combat actions, because it's ♥♥♥♥ing stupid that you can't sidestep easily
- allow climbing a ledge to be one of the combat actions, because it's ♥♥♥♥ing stupid that you can't climb a ledge in battle.
- change the controls so that you have to press another button to execute the jump, and possibly a different button if you want to jump but not collide with enemies, and another different button if you want to instead send out your grapple.
- make the jump indicator more reliable - in battle, it is your main control, it should do what you tell it to.
- give a ninja-sight option to go back a turn or two in battle if you (for example) ♥♥♥♥ up because the jump indicator lied to you
- give a way to incapacitate civs, because twice (TWICE!) one saw me just before a checkpoint, and couldn't avoid bonus objective failed.

reviewText:
2 aspects of the controls stink.  These make you character do things you arn't trying to do.  In a turn based game, that should not be an issue.

Aspect 1: special action icons
One would think you hover over a special action icon, it highlights (enlarging in this case), you click, when time resumes you do that action.  Well no.  You hover over the icon, it doesn't highlight, you click, and you jump (default mouse action is jumping if you aren't clicking an icon).  Instead, if you would mouse off the icon by the better half of an inch, then it gets big and you can click on it.  You could almost adapt to this wonky control if not for aspect 2.

Aspect 2: pausing
Press space or hold down mouse button to pause.  Mouse button also makes you do something, so when you just want to pause, space.  However, sometimes it's paused while you hold down space, and sometimes the space down press toggles pause.  This would almost be fine to introduce some reaction time and not make it entirely turn based, except when you are planning on it being turn based, and except for when combined with aspect 1 (real time clicking an icon, but you were supposed to hover, then move around until it gets big, and release before you move it more accidentally and make the icon small).

I think this would be a good game if the controls weren't all mucked up.

reviewText:
It's a fun game, but I wont reccommend a buy - if you got it in the Humble Bundle, by all means DL and have a look!

Game mechanics are so-so, the pause function is really bugging me, and a lot of other people on the discussion board. Some jumps gets unnessecarely complicated because of controls rather than level design, which is never a good thing.

Level design is mostly good, good balance between smooth parts and difficult parts, but there's no variation to the goals. Hack computers and kill bad guys, not a lot of variation on the enemies either.

The save function is automatic, and sometimes the save points end up really bad, and you have to reset the level, this is a big minus in my book.

The story is as thin as my coffee is black, I don't know why the devs even bothered to put in the small text, it wouldn't even have mattered if they left them out.



All in all it had potential, but fell short because of mechanics, too little variation and lack of story. I'd love to see a second game, with upgraded mechanics and more content and story.

reviewText:
I'll keep this short.  I loved this game.  It was enjoyable, despite some small control issues.  You had to approach each room like a puzzle, but could be creative on how you use your skills.  A few parts of the game were unintuitive, but even then they were beaten once you really took in your surroundings.

Then you make it to the final level.  It's the steaming pile to cap off an otherwise good game.  No checkpoints, enemies every two feet, and a unique mechanic that doesn't add much to the game, at least for me.  I've looked around, and many people have begged the developer to add checkpoints, and that the final level destroys what was an otherwise enjoyable game, but those pleas have fallen on deaf ears.

It's a shame, because I liked the game, but the final level ruins the whole experience.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So annoying. Just so annoying.

Listen, devs. I want to feel like a badass ninja assassin. It's not a stealth game? That's fine, nobody watched those old ninja movies to see people quietly sneak around. Killing's great. So why did you make it so, so stupid? Why do I have to spend so much time bouncing back and forth between enemies, gently knocking them to the ground so they can get up and shoot me in two turns? How about, you know, letting me kill them? A room of 9 enemies who can shoot the floor? Great, just let me kill them instead of pushing them around. It's just tedious. So, so tedious.

I won't describe the game, the gameplay's unique, go watch a video of it. But I will complain. You spend the majority of your time in turn-based mode, hopping around in arcs. You might think that since you're a badass assassin with a huge sword you'd use those hops to hop on enemies and stab them, but oh how wrong you'd be.

Your hops are for either knocking guys over or for avoiding 4 or 5 frozen laser beams representing enemy aim. Your hopping goal is not to hop ON the enemies to stab them or break their necks or anything, no that would be stupid. Your goal is to hop in such a way that the end of the turn finds you in the air somewhere NEAR an enemy. Should you achieve that, then next turn you can actually do the killing IF, and only if, none of the other 7 enemies are aiming somewhere that'll get you killed. Knowing THAT is complicated by the fact that where you end up after making a kill is somewhat random.

Actually your movement in general is a little random, particularly if you bump into an enemy but also for other reasons or no reason. Where exactly the enemies aim seems to vary a bit, which for better or worse adds an element of randomness to the levels which would otherwise play out the same way every time were you to use an identical approach.

Whatever. I'm sure it's a fine game if you're one of those people who find difficulty inherently fun. It's stylish and unique-ish. I just found it to be more annoying than enjoyable, and it made me want to stop playing real quick.

reviewText:
RONIN is pretty awesome. However, there are things I both like and dislike about it, so let's begin.

+ Cool art style
+ Good Music
+ Nice atmosphere
+ Works well with a Steam Controller
+ Combat is pretty fun, once you figure out how it works
+ Plot isn't integral to the gameplay, but still is mysterious and interesting
+ You get to be a badass ninja and slice guys in suits to pieces

- Achievments don't work on OSX
- The combat is difficult to learn at first
- The jump arc lies to you sometimes, causing you to screw up
- Momentum takes some getting used to
- Grappling hook tends to glich out if you grapple too fast (you can sometimes warp through the cieling)
- If you play a level too long, (more than about 30 mins) the game eventually straight up crashes.
- It seems a bit expensive for a game this short. (15 levels total)

So overall, Ronin is pretty fun, but it takes a while to get used to the slightly janky physics/combat. Once you do, it'll be a good time.

And why on earth did they think it was a good idea to make you re-play the entire game just to get an achievement?

Did I like it? Yes.
Does it have some problems? Yes.
Is it worth 12 dollers? No, but it is worth getting.

reviewText:
RONIN Not what it appears to be	I sent a refund request after I played the game to level 6 but realized the game was not at all what I thought it was. I thought from reviews that it was an open ended strategy game however from playing it to the 6th level I saw that it was a linear puzzle game with only one way to complete levels and at the 6th level I was forced to restart the game because I didn't choose the right abilities I needed.
The game might as well not give you a skill tree because you have to follow the right order and you only get one skill point per level, only if you furfill all three requirements: Kill all enemies, don't trigger the Alarm (lockdown) and spare all civillans.
all these requirements do is make the level longer and harder becuase without them you could pass all the levels in 5 minutes or so and the game often puts barriers of some kind to funnel you into going one path instead of it's open ended appearence.
this game has one good idea going for it, the turn-based/action combat system however that isn't enough to cover up the games false appearence.
I do not believe you should spend any money on this game.
update-
My steam refund request was denied because it went over the 2 hours mark.
I REPEAT DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE BUY THIS GAME

reviewText: The control scheme for mouse and keyboard is ridiculous. Although NOTHING in the game tells you this, attacking an enemy requires you to click the air above their head, and opening a door requires you to click the ground a few feet underneath it. Easily the single most unintuitive and ill-conceived scheme I have ever seen. The xbox controls are no better - the right stick will always waver on returning to the center, altering the direction of the jump a fraction of a second before it lauches. Incredibly frustrating.

reviewText:
Its so close to being a good game, but the mechanics were not properly refined before release.

Before combat you can do things like jump through the air and with skilled timing deploy a grappling hook at exacting angles, however when combat begins you lose all tactical choice, to a rigid time stopping mechanism.

Ideally something you would want to do is grapple swing through a window, and let go at the right angle to pounce on an enemy. But what happens is the rigid timing mechanism kicks in and you cant let go during the right angle ever.

The grappling hook in general seems like a whole afterthought, it doesn't give you any prediction guides, and often doesn't make sense enough to ever be useful in combat.
You never want to jump, and then grapple to stay in place, since they will shoot you there.
You never want to jump and then grapple in the opposite direction because it never swings you backward (i guess trying to respect the laws of momentum but not in a realistic enough way to be useful)
So I think the only real use of grapple in combat is jumping, and then swinging spiderman style in one direction only.

The fixed time slicing destroys any real tactical possibility in the game. Your jump turns into a white and red arc. The white part is where you will go this turn"  And you can only shoot your grapple at the exact ending of this turn. The way it should work is you should be able to lengthen or shorten this white area so that you could shoot the grapple at any point during the turn. Even with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ grapple physics
date: you would at least have some sense of control and more options. The way it is now you have LESS options during combat than free roaming.\n\nThere are bugs where you sometimes go through walls
recommended:
or don't get shot when you should have.

And finally: The way you tackle people mid jump is never consistent so you dont know where you will land or stop moving during the jump.

The end result is not a puzzle
hoursPlayed: nor tactical
voteText: you are just jumping around randomly hoping to get a kill every once in a while.\n\nInstead of actually fixing the game
helpfulPercent: the developer chose to just put a hint in the game that says "the arc is a lie" ♥♥♥♥ off"

reviewText:
Since Gunpoint was my favorite game of that year, I saw this game and thought i would love it. Sadly its too frustrating to completely have fun with it. While the combat is  moderately fun, the controls are pretty bad. Aiming the jump is harder than it should be, and I think is impossible with a controller. Also you have to do a lot of guesswork with jumping around the bullets, cause it does not show how your body will get to the point your jumping at, meaning you can never know if you will not touch a bullet when jumping. Another thing infuriating is that a couple of times i have glitch through the wall when jumping, which ins up killing me or triggering an alarm.
While some people have said there is no stealth, there is small parts of stealth if you want. To get skill points you need to complete a level killing all enemies, not killing civilians, and not triggering an alarm, and to avoid civilians triggering alarms you need to stealth past them, which is can be quite fun, but again can get ruin by the bad controls.
I really want to like this game, but there is too much holding me back from having fun in the moderate amount of fun there is in the combat.
Also the last level deserves a special place in hell

reviewText:
Ronin is a sidescroller that resembles Gunpoint to a certain degree. It has a similar jumping and platforming mechanic, but is a lot more combat focused. In fact, the great combat is the game's main selling point. Combat, unlike regular gameplay, is turn based, with enemy attacks being telegraphed via tracer lines. If you, during your turn, move out of the tracer trajectories, you dodge the attacks.

Pros:
+Combat is fun
+Atmospheric soundtrack
+Game is challenging

Cons:
-Locked to30FPS.
-The Skill system. In order to get skill points, you need to complete all three optional objectives of a map, making the optional" objectives not so optional at all.
-Paper thin story. There is almost no story at all.
-Controls could use some polish. The jump trajectory is unreliable.
-Linear level design. If you are used to Mark of the Ninja or Gunpoint
date: you will likely be disappointed\n-Final level has no checkpoints. Unlike regular levels
hoursPlayed: but get a 9 round countdown that refreshes each time you kill an enemy. If you kill the final boss while the countdown is active
voteText: you get the Bad End
helpfulPercent: but if you manage to kill him and escape without getting hit
votesHelpful: you get the Good End. Combine that with the great difficulty of the final map
votesTotal: and it is a recipe for frustration.\n\nI really want to like this game
votesFunny: and if the aforementioned issues get fixed then I will adjust my review accordingly."

reviewText: The game has some really cool ideas and when it all works you can pull off some really badass moves but the whole thing is mired in terrible controls and turn based" combat. Too often I would land next to a stunned enemy only to have to jump closer to him because I cant take two steps to get in attack range. In combat standard movement is entirely disabled and you can only traverse the world by jumping and using the grappling rope
date: which might be moderately acceptable except that the jump range that is pitiful and a grappling rope that is nigh on useless in combat. I would spend minutes bouncing around a room because I could stun enemies but be driven off before a killing blow. The "turns" are vague and on more than one occaision left me in a completely different position than I thought I would end in. The help tips told me nothing useful and if the message telling me that "the help tips are useful" is anything to go by they're lying to me too. On top of this is the sword enemy who I spent far too long trying to understand how to fight (because the game does not tell you anything). Turns out that jumping on them (like you would any other enemy) will only cause them to immediately kill you.\n\nThe game looks like something where you can plan your moves carefully and quickly (and bloodily) clear out a room of armed guards in a satisfying manner but it so rarely works out that way. After an hour
recommended: and the first two (of a supposed five if the game is to be believed) assassinations I've applied for a refund."

reviewText: The fundamental premise and game mechanics of RONIN are really good fun but it's let down by simply being too difficult. You need to play the same sections over and over and over to make progress and despite the game being fun, it's not fun enough to prevent it getting laborious.\n\nIt also suffers a bit from being obtuse, the tutorial and hints simply aren't good enough and so it'll take you a while to figure out some pretty basic stuff. If that wasn't enough, it also does that thing a lot of games do where it unlocks skills that make the game easier if you fulfill some pretty tricky criteria, essentially making the game easier for people who already find it easier and more difficult for people who are finding it difficult.

reviewText: While the idea behind the combat is interesting and the art and music are nice, I sadly can't recommend this game because of how inconsistent the movement is. In a game where one shot kills you and you have to plan very carefully because of that, the game needs to tell you exactly what locations are safe for the next turn, which kills are safe for the next turn, etc. I died so many times because I thought I could take that kill, but then one shot just touched my helmet, because of the position my body ended the turn in, or the other way around, where I was sure that shot would kill me, but then it went through my leg and nothing happened. That inconsistency just made the game too frustrating to play, which is sad, because when you actually manage to massacre an entire room full of gun-wielding agents and sci-fi-samurai with nothing but a sword (and some special abilites) you do feel pretty bad-♥♥♥.
