reviewText: Let me preface my review by saying that I enjoy hard games, and I enjoy turn based (and pseudo turn based) games.  Love FTL and Dark Souls, and a ton of different roguelikes.  I also grabbed this game for 50% off during the Stealth sale, so price, genre, and difficulty are not what's turning me off.\n\nRonin's problem is that it is trying to be a super tight action platformer with a turn based combat system, but the controls are clunky. (aka: the kiss of death for tight action games)  Everything your character can do is controlled by the mouse.  This is mostly fine during the turn based combat bits, but is horrid during the real time platform/stealth bits.  It means that instead of being able to swing in through a window, and tap a button to stab a guy in the back, you instead swing through the window, and have to click on a stab" button that pops up on screen by the enemy while your character (and the camera) are moving.  This gets especially annoying when you're also using the mouse to aim your next grappling hook. (or when you need to retract your grappling hook by clicking that icon
date: and quickly follow it up with a stealth kill
recommended:
requiring another)


Bugs were also plentiful in my short time with the game.  I was able to get my grappling hook to retract me through solid walls/ceilings several times.

One partifuclarly funny instance happened when I was trying to reach the last guard in a room before he sounded the alarm.  Was going to retract up to the ceiling and then pounce on him
hoursPlayed: but my grappling hook pulled me through to the roof.  Since there was no way to get back into the building from up there
voteText:
I had  no way to reach the guard before the alarm was set off.


Don't buy this game.  It's not a matter of money; you deserve better."

reviewText:
I tried this game with high hopes, but unfortunately the game kind of let me down. The way you need to get skill points to upgrade the game's hero, Jacket Conway, is tedious, put it nicely. You need to complete three bonus goals to get them, there's no other way. You need to spare the citizens, not trip the alarm, and kill all the enemies. This would have been fine if you DIDN'T HAVE THE CITIZENS BE ABLE TO TRIGGER A LOCKDOWN, and that wouldn't be as bad if the only way to prevent this was to straight up murder them. Now, perhaps I missed something here, but that seems very counter-productive in terms of allowing the player to get points for upgrades.



The clunky controls are something I can get over, once you get used to them, they aren't as much of a problem as the combat is. The regular security guards are okay, I like them. But the big swordsmen, oh they aren't much of a fun enemy to fight as they take two hits, and due to the turn-based battle system, which is something I like mind you, they get up at the end of the turn, making doing combat with just ONE involved becomes extremely tedious.



2/10 I suggest this game if you hate winning.

reviewText:
If you want a stealth game do not buy this.
There is no stealth.

MUST murder every single guard, it penalises you for not doing so.
Very linear - 1 entrance rooms with objectives inside, only one very specific way to do any given level.
Centred around clumsy turn-based jumpy stabby combat.
Trial and error (+weirdly placed checkpoints) instead of actually trying to figure out a puzzle

Additionally the skill system is terrible and the controls are pants, particularly the jumping.
One thing I will say is that the art style is really good and gives it a nice feel. Could look nicer if it wasn't locked to 30 fps for no reason.

I bought this because I love Gunpoint, but it looks like they forgot to copy all the good level design and humour
If you don't really care about stealth then you might like it, I guess. Or you could just play Mark of the Ninja and take the path of nightmares or might.


Am getting a refund, not sure if the review will stay :D

reviewText: A very interesting take on ninja combat, basically you're able to stop time whenever you want while in stealth, and combat is taken in turns rather than real time. Since it still plays mostly like an action platformer, this basically means gameplay is focused on tactical response on humanly impossible situations rather than quick button presses. (Kind of like how Frozen Synapse is basically a turnbased Counter-Strike) The approach it takes is also really good at making anyone feel like a badass ninja, while at the same time presenting some nice challenges.\n\nIt was fun and a nice change from other games, it deserves a sequel.

reviewText:
This game grabbed my attention from nowhere. I saw screw attack doing a live stream; so I checked it what was up.

This action turn based game really surprised me in the best possible way. Now here are many reasons why.
1. Level designs were fantastic and intuitive. First level was easy and perfect on learning the turn to time ratio. The last leave had me trying all the possible ways to get that last guy and out alive.
2. There is a reward based level up system that rewards clean and thoughtful playing. These new skills are earned but not taught letting you learn naturally the best situation to use combo points, here called the limit break.
3. Just enough story. There is some text for story at the beginning of some levels, and that is it. This is enough. It gives you the reason why the character is doing this and their point of view of the people she is hunting.
Now for the few gripes I have for the game. They are minor.
These two go together. One not enough enemy types. Three in total. Two game is short but not too short. Six hours at this writing, and that was for the not to spoil, which go into my last issue.



SPOILERS



There is no good or bad ending only getting through the last level in one peace.

reviewText:
This is an excellent concept, and and addictive and wonderful game. It really deserves a level editor to create custom challenges though, and the story is too short. Bugs and control issues may frustrate some.

Pros:
The core mechanic is excellent. Click and drag to jump in different directions. Use special abilities and basic attacks by clicking icons that appear over the heads of enemies. A simple skill tree adds variety to gameplay. Turn based combat makes it as much a strategic game as a tactical game.

Ronin's visual aesthetic is excellent. Little touches throughout the levels add flavor and a touch of lore given the game's minimalist approach to story telling.

Levels are well designed and interesting. Each level offers a unique set of challenges. The game tends to add 1 or 2 new mechanics per level, and introduces them very naturally.

The music works.

Some in game cutscenes and scripted moments through the game, and they are used effectively to convey story and even character (e.g., the first person you assassinate).

Cons:
The core mechanic does work the way you wish it would. Almost all players will run into a situation where they are within range of a platform if they jumped directly at it. But, because the jumps always seem to use the maximum arc, and only terminate if you hit specific structures, doing a straightish jump to a platform just in reach can be impossible. Likewise, if you jump and catch a ledge, there is no option to climb the ledge on your turn: you have to jump off the ledge. As it is, the only movement available during the turn based combat is the jump. Secondly, attack animations often seem ludicrous. When attacking a nearby target, you always jump in the air. So if a bullet is overhead, instead of stepping forward and thrusting, you leap into the bullet and die. These gameplay oddities destroy, for me, he suspension of disbelief. They are jarring to the point of distraction.

As others have mentioned, the game as bugs. I have only personally experienced the clip through ceiling" bug. I assume patches have alleviated most of the game-breaking bugs.

The music becomes repetitive after a while. It's almost always the same sound in the background.

The game is only about 4 hours long.

If you take certain alternative routes during the early missions
recommended: you will miss the tutorials. It seems the tutorials are keyed to passing through a given space
hoursPlayed: so if you don't pass through that space
voteText: no tutorial. This is most noticeable the first time you have to use the grappling hook to get somewhere.\n\nThe pause button doesn't always pause the game in the same places the jump button will. When you jump
helpfulPercent: the game pauses while you select your jump arc. The pause button (default space bar) will also pause the game while you hold it down. But the jump button will pause during moments when the space bar won't allow you to pause. Likewise
votesHelpful: you can't toggle pause (unless you click the jump button but cancel the jump).\n\nYou encounter samurai enemies from time to time. Unlike normal enemies
votesTotal: they chop you up if you jump into them. As far as I know
votesFunny: the game gives you no indication of this. So when you jump into one for the first time
column16: it slices you in half and you die. It would've been nice to see the samurai do this before encountering the first one that you can actually fight (in the first level there is one that just patrols around
column17:
but cannot be reached. I don't know why).

Game could use more cutscenes or scripted sequences.

Overall:
The core mechanic and level design overcomes the deficiencies of the game. It is worth playing
column18: especially at the <$10 price point. I think it would be worth >$15 if it only fixed some of the weird movement choices
column19: and maybe added a level editor.\n\n"

reviewText:
A pretty solid stealth game somewhere inbetween Mark of the Ninja and Gunpoint with a good ambient/chill-out soundtrack. Turn-based combat and time freezing mechanics add an interesting twist to the genre.
There are a few flaws though:
- controller support is pretty poor - I had to highly increase right stick sensitivity just to have my actions detected
- having to restart from the beginning when you exit a level it's quite punishing given the length of levels and the amount of randomness/luck implied in each combat
- some bugs let you unintentionally teleport through glass windows (which is cool) and slide through platforms (which is often not)

Overall I would recommend this game, hoping that programmer will add patches in the future.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
As a fan of Gunpoint I was eager to find similar experiences. RONIN takes a more combat-focused take on the concept, using an intuitive and simple turn system that is tactical and engaging. RONIN retains a stealth sytem like Gunpoint, but I feel that it can be almost abused with certain abilities (like the sword throw/retireve, check https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8faF2H5YcRc for a direct example)

RONIN also has some very annoying bugs that should really have been ironed out when it was in early access. Almost on-command you can grapple yourself through a wall into an inescapable room with literally no way out of. This can happen on every level, and sometimes even teleports you to the end of the level, particuraly the last one.

If you can look past this, and the rather high initial difficulty curve, RONIN is a great game with an amazing soundtrack too (seriously go listen to Swordpoint)

reviewText:
RONIN is a game that seeks to redifine what 'turn-based combat' means. Usually, when you hear the term, you think of JRPG style combat where people stand in place and rush each other to stab them with swords, chipping their mammoth HP before returning to their assigned positions and waiting for their next turn. RONIN is the opposite. It's about quick, mobile, fast-paced combat in which everyone can only take one hit. It's stylish and at its best it's brilliant.

RONIN is also a game about infiltrating buildings, Gunpoint-style. This second game is much worse than the first game, but it would be passable if it didn't use the same controls. Moving around and clicking on icons to perform moves work perfectly during the turn-based sections, but in the real-time infiltration period just turns things into a whack-a-mole. It is not always possible to 'ghost' levels, when it is it's clearly and afterthought, and even then it feels like you missed the main event of the excellent turn-based combat.

Even worse is the lockdown mechanic. If an enemy sees you, and then misses you, they'll call in a lockdown in ten seconds, unless you kill them first, or you enter their line of sight again. A lockdown will make the game slightly harder, and you only get to win a skill point at the end of a level if you fullfill three criteria, one of which is not having a lockdown called. So far so good. Except that enemies are super dumb. They will not take a single step to search you. If they see you, and you drop behind a low wall, they'll call a lockdown. If an enemy across the screen takes a short glimpse of you, they'll call in a lockdown. This means that very often during the game, instead of worrying about dying and killing enemies, I had to worry about trying to get to a small place so that a distant enemy will spot me again and cancel the lockdown. I had to do this every ten turns to stop the lockdown. I soon realized that when I screwed up and let the lockdown happen, I had a lot more fun with the game because I was focusing on dodging and countering attacks.

The game also has a very minimal story. It doesn't tell you who the protagonist is, for instance. Anyone with half a brain can figure it out in a minute; but I'm pretty certain that if this game had been released by an AAA publisher, not only would they tell you repeatedly about that, but they'd treat it as a mindblowing reveal. As it is, the story works flawlessly; just enough to give you a taste of what is happening and let you fill the huge blanks with your own imagination, if you even care to.

It's difficult not to recommend such a great game. But it's also difficult to overlook its flaws. There's even a tip in the loading screen that says it's not a stealth game, so I don't know why it goes through its motions so often if it knows it isn't one. It's like an excellent RTS game that forces you to play a race between each level, using the same controls from the RTS sections, and how you place in the race affects how much resoursces you get. Here's hoping the next game focuses more on the combat and the infiltration is reduced to a sideshow, or even completely eliminated.

reviewText:
RONIN is a mix of Gunpoint and Mark of the Ninja, and although it lacks the depth and replayability of either of those, it still ends up being a lot of fun. The combat system is, once you get the hang of it, enjoyable to play around with, and the various powerups you can purchase do end up altering your playstyle.

A few issues:

There isn't much variation on offer. Unlike Gunpoint or MotN, there's only a handful of ways to clear a level. You also have to kill everyone (and have no alarms raised) to get a skill point from a level, and pretty much all the levels have mandatory combat sessions, so there's no option to simply stealth through the game, which is a bit of a disappointment. You can, in certain cases, sneak around before the inevitable fight and thin the enemy forces a bit, but this isn't always an option and it doesn't head off the reinforcements that often show up.

Level design also suffers from this - there's often one way in and out of the location, or maybe two, and a clear 1-2-3 path you're expected to follow. This is a shame, because this type of game can and should offer a much larger variety in terms of reaching the objectives, so as to best make use of the stealth mechanics. Instead, it feels a little too linear.

I haven't completed the game, but from what I've seen of the level design and skills on offer, there isn't much replay value. This stems in part from the above problem with variation, but also because there often isn't reason to go back to earlier levels with new skills. The skill points from each level can be unlocked as you play it the first time, and there are no collectibles or points to worry about.

Combat also, especially with larger numbers of enemies, turns into a trial-and-error system, where you figure out the best opening move, then replicate it as you try out the potential avenues of attack after that, going for a new strategy on the last branch each time you die. While it's actually sort of fun to outsmart the enemy soldiers and finally get the strategy that takes them all down, it can get a little frustrating, especially given the occasional variance in jump and bullet predictions.

Ultimately, though, this game (for all its flaws) is a lot of fun. Playing with the combat mechanics, figuring out ways to bypass civilians or sneak up on enemies, replaying a tough section to kill all guards without letting them get an alarm out, all add up to an enjoyable experience, for a few hours at least. While it's not quite worth the asking price, at a decent discount it's a great purchase.

It's like an excellent RTS game that forces you to play a race between each level, using the same controls from the RTS sections, and how you place in the race affects how much resoursces you get. Here's hoping the next game focuses more on the combat and the infiltration is reduced to a sideshow, or even completely eliminated.

reviewText:
This is not a stealth game.
This is not a gunpoint clone.

Once you get rid of those two thoughts and get your head around the reactive/tactical combat system the game really flows smoothly. After you unlock some skills and get some practice with aiming the jumps and grapple swings you will float through rooms of enemies like a Pinball of death.

It's a bit short,It took just about 5 hours for me to get through the game with completing all the optional goals on all the levels.There is a new game+ that let's you play through again with slightly harder enemies while keeping all your unlocked abilities.

As of writing this on 9/19/15 there is an occasional bug which lead to you or an enemy getting knock though a wall but it doesn't happen often and the checkpoint system means it's not even close to being a game breaker.

Another negative is that the story is almost non existent.

All in all I'd say it's just about worth buying at full price for the experience. If you ever get the chance to buy it for under $9 I'd say it's well worth it.

My only bad things about this game is that it is;

3) All of the side objectives (used to unlock new skills) are all the same. No variation at all, saddly.

Overall I would give this a 7.5/10, If you have spare money to buy it with, go for it. Otherwise, I would definitely pick this up on sale!

reviewText:
As a fan of Gunpoint I was eager to find similar experiences. RONIN takes a more combat-focused take on the concept, using an intuitive and simple turn system that is tactical and engaging. RONIN retains a stealth sytem like Gunpoint, but I feel that it can be almost abused with certain abilities (like the sword throw/retireve, check https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8faF2H5YcRc for a direct example)

RONIN also has some very annoying bugs that should really have been ironed out when it was in early access. Almost on-command you can grapple yourself through a wall into an inescapable room with literally no way out of. This can happen on every level, and sometimes even teleports you to the end of the level, particuraly the last one.

If you can look past this, and the rather high initial difficulty curve, RONIN is a great game with an amazing soundtrack too (seriously go listen to Swordpoint)

reviewText: This game has a great core mechanic that slows down the pace of the game but makes you feel like a badass more than it would have if the whole thing took place in real time. When your best option is to take out as many guards as possible before they figure out what's going on, it's exciting and tense all at once, as well as gratifying when you pull it off. The grappling hook mechanic takes some getting used to - I'd recommend a mouse and keyboard for precision - but once you get the hang of it, as well as the nuances of movement, you feel like Spider-Man with a sword. My only problem is there are a couple of jumping bugs that screwed me over, which is especially problematic for the New Game Plus mode I'm currently in the middle of which adds machine gun guards early on and changes certain enemy behavior. But overall, there aren't any  issues that can't be addressed in a sequel. So, where is it?

reviewText:
RONIN is a game that seeks to redifine what 'turn-based combat' means. Usually, when you hear the term, you think of JRPG style combat where people stand in place and rush each other to stab them with swords, chipping their mammoth HP before returning to their assigned positions and waiting for their next turn. RONIN is the opposite. It's about quick, mobile, fast-paced combat in which everyone can only take one hit. It's stylish and at its best it's brilliant.

RONIN is also a game about infiltrating buildings, Gunpoint-style. This second game is much worse than the first game, but it would be passable if it didn't use the same controls. Moving around and clicking on icons to perform moves work perfectly during the turn-based sections, but in the real-time infiltration period just turns things into a whack-a-mole. It is not always possible to 'ghost' levels, when it is it's clearly and afterthought, and even then it feels like you missed the main event of the excellent turn-based combat.

Even worse is the lockdown mechanic. If an enemy sees you, and then misses you, they'll call in a lockdown in ten seconds, unless you kill them first, or you enter their line of sight again. A lockdown will make the game slightly harder, and you only get to win a skill point at the end of a level if you fullfill three criteria, one of which is not having a lockdown called. So far so good. Except that enemies are super dumb. They will not take a single step to search you. If they see you, and you drop behind a low wall, they'll call a lockdown. If an enemy across the screen takes a short glimpse of you, they'll call in a lockdown. This means that very often during the game, instead of worrying about dying and killing enemies, I had to worry about trying to get to a small place so that a distant enemy will spot me again and cancel the lockdown. I had to do this every ten turns to stop the lockdown. I soon realized that when I screwed up and let the lockdown happen, I had a lot more fun with the game because I was focusing on dodging and countering attacks.

The game also has a very minimal story. It doesn't tell you who the protagonist is, for instance. Anyone with half a brain can figure it out in a minute; but I'm pretty certain that if this game had been released by an AAA publisher, not only would they tell you repeatedly about that, but they'd treat it as a mindblowing reveal. As it is, the story works flawlessly; just enough to give you a taste of what is happening and let you fill the huge blanks with your own imagination, if you even care to.

It's difficult not to recommend such a great game. But it's also difficult to overlook its flaws. There's even a tip in the loading screen that says it's not a stealth game, so I don't know why it goes through its motions so often if it knows it isn't one. It's like an excellent RTS game that forces you to play a race between each level, using the same controls from the RTS sections, and how you place in the race affects how much resoursces you get. Here's hoping the next game focuses more on the combat and the infiltration is reduced to a sideshow, or even completely eliminated.

reviewText:
This is an excellent concept, and and addictive and wonderful game. It really deserves a level editor to create custom challenges though, and the story is too short. Bugs and control issues may frustrate some.

Pros:
The core mechanic is excellent. Click and drag to jump in different directions. Use special abilities and basic attacks by clicking icons that appear over the heads of enemies. A simple skill tree adds variety to gameplay. Turn based combat makes it as much a strategic game as a tactical game.

Ronin's visual aesthetic is excellent. Little touches throughout the levels add flavor and a touch of lore given the game's minimalist approach to story telling.

Levels are well designed and interesting. Each level offers a unique set of challenges. The game tends to add 1 or 2 new mechanics per level, and introduces them very naturally.

The music works.

Some in game cutscenes and scripted moments through the game, and they are used effectively to convey story and even character (e.g., the first person you assassinate).

Cons:
The core mechanic does work the way you wish it would. Almost all players will run into a situation where they are within range of a platform if they jumped directly at it. But, because the jumps always seem to use the maximum arc, and only terminate if you hit specific structures, doing a straightish jump to a platform just in reach can be impossible. Likewise, if you jump and catch a ledge, there is no option to climb the ledge on your turn: you have to jump off the ledge. As it is, the only movement available during the turn based combat is the jump. Secondly, attack animations often seem ludicrous. When attacking a nearby target, you always jump in the air. So if a bullet is overhead, instead of stepping forward and thrusting, you leap into the bullet and die. These gameplay oddities destroy, for me, he suspension of disbelief. They are jarring to the point of distraction.

As others have mentioned, the game as bugs. I have only personally experienced the clip through ceiling" bug. I assume patches have alleviated most of the game-breaking bugs.

The music becomes repetitive after a while. It's almost always the same sound in the background.

The game is only about 4 hours long.

If you take certain alternative routes during the early missions
recommended: you will miss the tutorials. It seems the tutorials are keyed to passing through a given space
hoursPlayed: so if you don't pass through that space
voteText: no tutorial. This is most noticeable the first time you have to use the grappling hook to get somewhere.\n\nThe pause button doesn't always pause the game in the same places the jump button will. When you jump
helpfulPercent: the game pauses while you select your jump arc. The pause button (default space bar) will also pause the game while you hold it down. But the jump button will pause during moments when the space bar won't allow you to pause. Likewise
votesHelpful: you can't toggle pause (unless you click the jump button but cancel the jump).\n\nYou encounter samurai enemies from time to time. Unlike normal enemies
votesTotal: they chop you up if you jump into them. As far as I know
votesFunny: the game gives you no indication of this. So when you jump into one for the first time
column16: it slices you in half and you die. It would've been nice to see the samurai do this before encountering the first one that you can actually fight (in the first level there is one that just patrols around
column17:
but cannot be reached. I don't know why).

Game could use more cutscenes or scripted sequences.

Overall:
The core mechanic and level design overcomes the deficiencies of the game. It is worth playing
column18: especially at the <$10 price point. I think it would be worth >$15 if it only fixed some of the weird movement choices
column19: and maybe added a level editor.\n\n"

A pretty solid stealth game somewhere inbetween Mark of the Ninja and Gunpoint with a good ambient/chill-out soundtrack. Turn-based combat and time freezing mechanics add an interesting twist to the genre.

Overall I would recommend this game, hoping that programmer will add patches in the future.

reviewText:
One of the hardest games I've played and that's without exaggeration. Maybe it's just getting used to it but the game is really designed in a way to make it incredibly hard for you to adapt to any situation it presents... And I... like this.

It is very hard to explain how RONIN works but it's a mix of real-time platforming and turn-based combat. What made the game hard for me is that I wanted to 100% all the stages, which meant no civilian kills, no alarms raised and every enemy in the stage has to be dead. Having to do all of this and keeping your sanity is very hard as the game constantly throws unfair room set-ups at you. I swear, had it not been for some of the more useful skills like the stun or the shadow strike (teleport), this game would be only for the most hardcore of masochists, and even then, they may give up on it. Having to repeat the same level over 40 times, figuring out the best way to kill everyone without setting off an alarm and keeping track of every line aimed at you or your surroundings and the one who's aiming it (could be a one shot, could be a rifle guy who fires for 2 turns or worse: a samurai that dashes through everything in his path).

I will admit, I did ragequit several times, which was a big mistake since the game doesn't remember checkpoints in the level if you leave it, so i had to start over again. All of the missions are varied in terms of stage design, not so much in objectives. The level is usually hack these terminals

reviewText:
Don't buy into all the negative reviews, this game is treated unjustly. Why? Because alot of people just could not grasp the concept.

RONIN is an interesting blend of platforming, stealth, turn based-strategy and action game unlike anything you have played specifically, but reminscent of many games you have. All of it comes together nicely with a simple yet effective art style, music and level design. The story has a thin narrative but it does the job well enough establishing a cyber-punk samurai tale of revenge.

The controls (I used Mouse+Keyboard) were responsive and tightly tuned and they really let me sink my teeth into the finer nuances of combat such as letting bullets graze me and threading those jumps.

The game poses a moderate challenge even for a veteran gamer as it is not a simple hack+slash stealth game, but actually requires you to think ahead and attack at the right time or even the right angle. The learning curve is real and you will die until you ~GET GUD~ but not as much as these negative reviews would have you believe.

The players have all the advantages in the wonderful combat of RONIN, they only need use them!

Highly recommended

reviewText:
This is a tactical assassination game with some stealth elements. Essentially, you're supposed to kill every single combatant in pause-based combat while avoiding detection by non-coms.

It *is* quite as interesting as it sounds, but also extremely frustrating at times due to a few design problems.

1. During combat, you will occasionally end up in a position that affords no good jump trajectories (e.g., clinging to the side of the building you are assaulting). When this happens, you do not have the option to simply climb up and continue your attack, forcing you to make a bad jump.

2. If you kill all nearby mooks, you snap out of combat mode even if you are in view of a farther away enemy. The moment or two you need to realize you're no longer in pause mode but are in real-time mode can cost you a perfect win.

3. The single-auto-save system doesn't always work well. It sometimes saves at an inconvenient time (e.g., after a civilian has spotted you), causing you to have to replay the entire level.

These three problems may not seem so bad, but I promise you they will cause you to hate the game from time to time. Overall score: 6.5 / 10

reviewText:
Reminds me of Gunpoint, which I would *highly* recommend, (which is nice because the one drawback of that game was its short-ish lenght) but instead of hacking into electical grids as a companion to turn-by-turn jumping and stabbing action, this game has perks you can get by completing level acheivements, then invest in a perk tree. In-game, each time you bump and enemy or kill them you get a few points, which you can then use on your perk abilities you have at the moment. Fun concept and can be quite fun in places.

However, not only does it crash relatively often, always erasing your progress within the level (on a Mac if that makes a difference), there are a few other very frustrating aspects of the game. Too often you find yourself in a wide open space surrounded by an unreasonable amount of baddies, and I find a few levels to be maddeningly difficult. And that's a bug, not a feature. It's this failure to actually create a pleasing game that puts me right on the fence of a thumbs up or a thumbs down. RONIN deserves its mixed review due to crashing and levels that, while cool, were not quite thought out/played enough, and it constantly drives me away from the game to go play something else more reasonable.

The soundtrack is generally enjoyable.

reviewText:
RONIN is a game that I have been really dissapointed because I really liked the demo and loved the concept of this ninja/cyberpunk theme turn-based action game with the level design fo Gunpoint.

STORY:
Sadly there isn't much of a story to tell, as the game tries to be mysterious with the masked ninja protagonist, no real reason or motivation of  why you are  killing these people on the photo. And I know that i haven't made much of progress in the game so if anyone who reads this review tell me if there's anything happens in the story.

Presentation: It good but not amazing, I like the dark cyberpuck feel of the game, I esspecially loved the design of those futuristic Samurai enemies you fight in the game. Though the building are quite lackluster and too similar to one another and the blood often spread too thin when stabbing people making look less guresome than it should be. the music is ok, it sort-off fit the gameplay if it wasn't for the odd voices singing in the soundtrack but to me, it's really forgettable.

Gameplay: RONIN is like a said before a turnbased action game in a level design very similar to Gunpoint. You move in real-time with the WASD keys and use the mouse to aim and launch our mysterious ninja into windows, hung on walls and  survive mass falls just like our favouite spy-for-hire in Gunpoint. but what makes it unique from Gunpoint is when an enemy spotted you the game ssitch from real-time to turn based with youre only control is the mouse to stratigically fight agianist muliple enemies in a room. let's remember that you can only take one hit so it's important so don't go in ramboing all over the place.
You know I sound quite negitive so far to the game and it's because that I would have been whistling a different tune if it's wasn't for the  probelsm in the gameplay . The controls while simple can have annoying problems sometimes. what i mean is that MANY times during the game the mouse can suddenly change to feel as if it was inverted and you have to waste seconds to go to where you want to leap from WITH NO REASON. If it was a bug I'm experiencing, then why it wasn't fix the game was released in May 2015 and i bought this game in the same month 2016!!!

But let's get into the meat of what the BIGGEST problem in the game and that is that this game is FUSTRATING. No not difficult or challenging but really fustrating. Why? Well it is that since that every shot from the laser-pointed guns and one stab of the cyber-samurai's katanas will kill you, you will be doing what i call this stratagy dodge the bullet/ blade minigame as every-time you try to to kill an enemy, there will be 13 other enemies aiming their weapons at you and you'll know that you can't kill the enemy and survive an this keep going one for ever and eventually you are going to die and have to replay that section again. It so repetitive and lose the fun of being a crazy ninja and that's why i stop playing this game an hour in and request for a refund becuase I know that even i made though these sections of the game will be boring and in the end i perfer to have fun playing video games.

I really don't recommend this game, for those who are still intrested in this game, I recommend by the demo as it has less enemy placement and good level design so you'll have more fun playing the game rather than buying and playing the full game.

reviewText:
This is a tactical assassination game with some stealth elements. Essentially, you're supposed to kill every single combatant in pause-based combat while avoiding detection by non-coms.

It *is* quite as interesting as it sounds, but also extremely frustrating at times due to a few design problems.

1. During combat, you will occasionally end up in a position that affords no good jump trajectories (e.g., clinging to the side of the building you are assaulting). When this happens, you do not have the option to simply climb up and continue your attack, forcing you to make a bad jump.

2. If you kill all nearby mooks, you snap out of combat mode even if you are in view of a farther away enemy. The moment or two you need to realize you're no longer in pause mode but are in real-time mode can cost you a perfect win.

3. The single-auto-save system doesn't always work well. It sometimes saves at an inconvenient time (e.g., after a civilian has spotted you), causing you to have to replay the entire level.

These three problems may not seem so bad, but I promise you they will cause you to hate the game from time to time. Overall score: 6.5 / 10

reviewText:
Product received for free

A game that really needed some polishing. Absolutely fantastic concept, really poor execution.

I started off with no knowledge of the controls, and was thoroughly confused when attempting to do basic movement. I am told that others got a prompt with controls, but I somehow skipped it unknowingly.
Next, I find the escape menu that tells you some challenges. No alarms, kill all enemies, kill no civilians. Right then. I immediately find an inaccessible enemy, and, assuming I want to complete the challenge, get frustrated as I see no way to access this enemy. He doesn't count apparently.

Next, the movement system sucks. It never feels like the character is doing what I actually want it to. Even when out of combat and just using WASD, the main character just doesn't feel good to control. Would it kill you to put in a jump" button? Maybe I don't want to do a time-stopping leap across the room. I just wanna jump a few feet up.

The platforms are terrible. The actual platforms are mechanically obnoxious. You can't grab onto them
date: despite the game seemingly relying heavily on the wall latch system. In combat

reviewText:
RONIN is a game that I have been really dissapointed because I really liked the demo and loved the concept of this ninja/cyberpunk theme turn-based action game with the level design fo Gunpoint.

STORY:
Sadly there isn't much of a story to tell, as the game tries to be mysterious with the masked ninja protagonist, no real reason or motivation of  why you are  killing these people on the photo. And I know that i haven't made much of progress in the game so if anyone who reads this review tell me if there's anything happens in the story.

Presentation: It good but not amazing, I like the dark cyberpuck feel of the game, I esspecially loved the design of those futuristic Samurai enemies you fight in the game. Though the building are quite lackluster and too similar to one another and the blood often spread too thin when stabbing people making look less guresome than it should be. the music is ok, it sort-off fit the gameplay if it wasn't for the odd voices singing in the soundtrack but to me, it's really forgettable.

Gameplay: RONIN is like a said before a turnbased action game in a level design very similar to Gunpoint. You move in real-time with the WASD keys and use the mouse to aim and launch our mysterious ninja into windows, hung on walls and  survive mass falls just like our favouite spy-for-hire in Gunpoint. but what makes it unique from Gunpoint is when an enemy spotted you the game ssitch from real-time to turn based with youre only control is the mouse to stratigically fight agianist muliple enemies in a room. let's remember that you can only take one hit so it's important so don't go in ramboing all over the place.
You know I sound quite negitive so far to the game and it's because that I would have been whistling a different tune if it's wasn't for the  probelsm in the gameplay . The controls while simple can have annoying problems sometimes. what i mean is that MANY times during the game the mouse can suddenly change to feel as if it was inverted and you have to waste seconds to go to where you want to leap from WITH NO REASON. If it was a bug I'm experiencing, then why it wasn't fix the game was released in May 2015 and i bought this game in the same month 2016!!!

But let's get into the meat of what the BIGGEST problem in the game and that is that this game is FUSTRATING. No not difficult or challenging but really fustrating. Why? Well it is that since that every shot from the laser-pointed guns and one stab of the cyber-samurai's katanas will kill you, you will be doing what i call this stratagy dodge the bullet/ blade minigame as every-time you try to to kill an enemy, there will be 13 other enemies aiming their weapons at you and you'll know that you can't kill the enemy and survive an this keep going one for ever and eventually you are going to die and have to replay that section again. It so repetitive and lose the fun of being a crazy ninja and that's why i stop playing this game an hour in and request for a refund becuase I know that even i made though these sections of the game will be boring and in the end i perfer to have fun playing video games.

I really don't recommend this game, for those who are still intrested in this game, I recommend by the demo as it has less enemy placement and good level design so you'll have more fun playing the game rather than buying and playing the full game.

reviewText: Ronin is a very interesting mixture of stealth, platform and puzzle mechanics. When the character is undiscovered by the enemies the game plays like a platformer, when the guards find out where you are the turn based combat phase starts. The enemies start to shoot at the player and/or call for reinforcement. The combat is based around carefully planned jumps and the use of the ninja abilities unlocked completing the missions. The game can be really hard until you understand how to stealthy pick off the guards without getting discovered by the remaining enemies. Many of the most difficult scenarios can be easily resolved if you manage to thin down the number of the guards, especially the heavily armed ones. Still sometimes not getting shot is a matter of luck, especially in the new game plus where the assault rifle guard becomes much more powerful. I have enjoyed this game very much since it's pretty unique but I understand that the gameplay may not appeal to everyone. Think about buying Ronin if you are not scared of a game that may require many tries before you can finally pass a difficult section.

reviewText:
Product received for free

A game that really needed some polishing. Absolutely fantastic concept, really poor execution.

I started off with no knowledge of the controls, and was thoroughly confused when attempting to do basic movement. I am told that others got a prompt with controls, but I somehow skipped it unknowingly.
Next, I find the escape menu that tells you some challenges. No alarms, kill all enemies, kill no civilians. Right then. I immediately find an inaccessible enemy, and, assuming I want to complete the challenge, get frustrated as I see no way to access this enemy. He doesn't count apparently.

Next, the movement system sucks. It never feels like the character is doing what I actually want it to. Even when out of combat and just using WASD, the main character just doesn't feel good to control. Would it kill you to put in a jump" button? Maybe I don't want to do a time-stopping leap across the room. I just wanna jump a few feet up.

The platforms are terrible. The actual platforms are mechanically obnoxious. You can't grab onto them

reviewText: Wow, what an absolute diamond in the rough. This game was a blast all the way through. I've died countless times playing it, but the beauty was that it takes a lot of thought and strategy. Once you figure out a strategy it becomes a game of cat and mouse. It's turn based once you get into combat, but I wouldn't have it any other way. I gives you time to think about your next move. When you finally do make those correct choices, it becomes so satisfying that you want more.\n\nIf you're into thinking, action, and want something a little different. I'd definitely give this one a go.

reviewText:
So I bought this Devolver Digital Humble Bundle, and got this along with the games I bought it for. I decided to try it out, and was surprised how amazing it was. It has an overall similarity with Mark of the Ninja, but more non-stealth and one-shot-death, like Hotline Miami, both games that I am very fond of. The story is pretty solid, and the gameplay is challenging, but not unnecessary forced difficult. And the change of death-gameplay in the last level made me like it even more. There are of cause bugs and small quirks, that can be a tiny bit frustrating, but nothing that makes the game unplayable. And the New Game Plus mode. Don't get me started! Besides starting of with all of your strong abilities and your experience from the basic game, the challenge of the enemies moving their aim instead of just shooting at where you were.

Advantages:
-Neat story
-Fun and challenging gameplay
-Nice Original Soundtrack
-Fun level design
-Simple, yet functioning skill tree
-Good series potential (Gameplay, not story)

Disadvantages:
-Can get a bit difficult
-Elevators are INFINITELY slow
-Way too short!
-Bug with enemies getting stuck in walls, making them unkillable and prompting them to sound the alarm (Very frustrating)
-Closed ending, no plot for sequel

So to sum up:
Great game, would probably buy it for full price. Few bugs, nothing to worry about. 9.5/10

reviewText: Ronin is a really interesting concept which takes familiar elements from other popular indie titles and tries to create something new and compelling, but ulitimately it fails to deliver due to frustrating controls and unintuitive behavior.  Ronin behaves like a typical 2d platformer where the player can freely run, jump and climb around the environment, but when the player is spotted by a guard the games shifts to a turn-based system where the player selects an action (jump, attack or special ability) at the same time as the AI. Many people will compare this game with Gunpoint as the games have similar aesthetics and somewhat similar movement system, but while Gunpoint is more of a puzzle game focused on manipulating the environment, Ronin is all about the combat. Ronin still feels like a puzzle as you try to trace a path through the enemy gunfire and pick off your opponents one by one, but feels very different in the heat of the moment. When you are dodging through the environment executing guards using the perfect ability for the situation you feel like a god, however due to the controls often you will find yourself stumbling directly into what should be easily avoidable gunfire. Many times the difference between success and failure feels like a mere pixel. Thankfully most of the levels have checkpoints centered around the main set pieces of each level, but there was an instance in a later level where the checkpoint was saved as a guard discovered me, removing any advantage of surprise I could leverage. I ended up quiting the game during the final level which removed all checkpoints and just watched the ending on Youtube. Overall I really enjoyed some moments of the game, but the moments of frustration were too frequent to recommend this game. If you are looking for a similar experience I would highly recommend both Gunpoint and Mark of the Ninja as similar titles with much better controls and a better overall experience.
